title: Which party will win Ohio's 12th Congressional District special election?
preds: Making a huuuuuuge shift after all of the lunacy that the GOP and their candidate have been unleashing over the past week.

Polls statistically dead heat  - The Emerson poll is one of the least biased in US
https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/everything-you-need-to-know-about-the-ohio-12th-special-election/

As an afterthought, Munchin CoS Eli Miller has deep Ohio conservative connections that were not given enuf coverage in today's Bloomberg Politik piece.  Could his quiet clout make a difference for the GOP... Link http://ohioconservativereview.com/eli-miller/

HuffPo (Verizon owned) sez race is narrowing. https://www.huffpostbrasil.com/entry/democrats-gop-house-seat-ohio_us_5b647a14e4b0fd5c73d9202 A possible collateral affect that could hurt GOP more than the Donkeys are the various and sundry mendacities about spousal abuse by a football coach of "student-athletes" at the nearby Ohia State University and what Head Coach Urban Meyer knew, revealed
Strong Republican District. Trump & Kasich endorsed candidate. Polls show Republican with double digit lead with less than week to go.
Balderson (R) up in the polls, but with voter interest low and party spending high, results might surprise.

Trump endorses Balderson in battleground OH-12 special election, his eighth U.S. House endorsement of the year
President Donald Trump endorsed state Sen. Troy Balderson (R) in the August 7 special election for Ohio’s 12th Congressional District against Franklin County Recorder Danny O’Connor (D). He tweeted, “Troy Balderson of Ohio is running for Congress against a Nancy Pelosi Liberal who is WEAK on Crime & Borders. Troy is the total opposite, and loves our Military, Vets & 2nd Amendment. EARLY VOTING just started with Election Day on August 7th. Troy has my Full & Total Endorsement!” Balderson calls himself a strong supporter of President Trump, who won the district by a margin of 11 points. He supports the construction of a wall along the U.S.-Mexico border and an Obamacare replacement that requires health insurance to cover pre-existing conditions. O’Connor is running as a moderate candidate, calling for a change in congressional leadership from both House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) and pledging to work with Republicans and Trump to fix infrastructure. Balderson is the eighth candidate for U.S. House to be endorsed by Trump this year. He won the Republican primary in the OH-12 special election on May 8.

Trump carried this district by 11 points.  The 10 year Republican resigned knowing that this election was a Dem sweep in his district.  R registration does exceed the Dems, but, 2016 was a vote against Clinton, not for Trump.  The Republican candidate is a farmer, anti-abortion rights activist, gun rights advocate and supports the "wall".  The Dem is an attorney, small business owner, concerned with jobs, health care and protecting social security.  The district is industrial, agricultural, educational with a significant population of middle-class suburban voters, who, this year are becoming aware.  More people did vote in the R primary, however, the winner there achieved less than 30%  In a large field the Dem achieved 40%.  The R has endorsements from the former Congressman and the Lickin County Auditor.  The Dem. is endorsed by former governors and all current Ohio Dem. Congressmen.  in 2018 the growing suburban vote will go to anyone but the Republicans.
Can't see any reason the GOP would suddenly lose the 12th district

Cook Political Report has this as a toss up [1]. Not sure how to translate this into probabilistic terms. Their definition of a toss up is "These are the most competitive; either party has a good chance of winning" so unsure how to interpret. O'Connor has an edge in early voting numbers in traditional Republican areas. He could appeal to voters as somebody who is married to a Republican. On the other hand, the timing could contribute to a low turnout which should play in favor of the Republicans. [2] [1] https://www.cookpolitical.com/ratings/house-race-ratings
[2] https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/13/us/politics/ohio-special-election-house.html
Shifting a few points toward the republicans based on their ten point lead in two polls in June.

Living in Ohio, I see a continued rebound against the Democrats as frustration with Brown and others lend themselves to a knee-jerk reaction on one hand, and a complimentary support of perceived, if marginal improvement in local economies.

This district is heavily gerrymandered R.  A really big turnout in the Columbus burbs could help the Ds make a good show of it, but probably not enough to take the seat, especially since the burbs that are in the district are the more conservative ones.  Still, the world is full of surprises lately.
Nasty partisan infighting between 2 cardboard cuttouts and a democrat.  And thats just on the republican side.
It's like PA-18 but less good for Dems.

Rosenberger resignation opens new front in Ohio speakership battle
Cliff RosenbergerOhio state House Speaker Cliff Rosenberger’s (R) surprise resignation over an FBI investigation has muddled the 2019 speakership race between state Reps. Ryan Smith (R) and Larry Householder (R). Interim Speaker Kirk Schuring (R) will decide when Rosenberger’s successor is selected. If Smith or Householder serves out the remainder of Rosenberger’s term as speaker, that person could improve his standing for the 2019 race. Schuring could also stay in the job, or appoint another caretaker speaker, to serve out the 2018 term. Such a move would put the choice of speaker in voters’ hands, as Householder and Smith are backing competing slates of candidates in the GOP primaries. Smith, who chairs the House Finance Committee, says he has the support of the majority of the chamber’s GOP incumbents. His close relationship with Rosenberger, however, might cause some to reconsider. Householder also faced an FBI investigation related to campaign finance improprieties when he previously served as speaker in the early 2000s. He was not charged with a crime.
The shift from safe Republican to likely republican coupled with democratic enthusiasm and the weight of the Columbus suburbs.
Trump's margin in this district was only 9%. Pols say it leans republican.
A reliably R district historically it seems, which Trump took with an 8..6% margin, gerrymandered as others have noted. R candidates' combined war chest is an order of magnitude larger.

This was Kasich territory before Tiberi glommed on to it. Heavily gerrymandered, historically GOP.  538 has tried to put a stats-based "truth in journalism" jacket on the total group of "mass resignations" in Congress that started in January of this year to no avail. There is no Sotto Voce in this little political opera but there ought to be. Incumbent US senator liberal DEM Sherrod Brown has been moving toward political center, supporting Trump on steel quotas, not likely to help DEM survivor of Louisiana-style "jungle" primary and Kasich will stay away since Trump team and their "contractors" have a certain someone in mind here. Inquiring minds might wanna take a look at why secretary of state and Irak war vet Clevelander Josh Mandel dropped out of Republican senate primary in January maybe pick up couple two three clues;)  Or DeWine's latest machinations...   http://www.cleveland.com/open/index.ssf/2018/04/mike_dewine_told_ohio_speaker.html#incart_river_index
What a dumb question. Seriously CNN. The kids today.
effective GOP gerrymandering all but guarantees the outcome of this odd-shaped district

This is John Kasich's old district. It was reconstructed to divide the Columbus and near suburban vote and make this one even more solidly R than previously, which was pretty solid.  It will matter some who wins the primaries, because there are some D-leaning Columbus burbs in the district, so D turnout might help some if the right (or wrong) candidates are on the ballot.   It would be quite the upset if a D won.  Looking at the map, I don't see a lot of blue areas, but I haven't worked in Ohio politics for 20+ years; this means you should disregard anything I say.

As a lifelong Ohioan, I have to wonder why this question is even being asked.   Here's where the 12th District is:  https://www.govtrack.us/congress/members/OH/12
Here's are results maps for the past 58 years:  http://www.cleveland.com/datacentral/index.ssf/2016/06/ohio_presidential_election_res_2.html?appSession=6707FRQ337J1051EBNI24P5ZGU33G5K8LU833SO06ZB00N16XION4ZG68SV1FIT5S97IOD10DLI1Q9345E3533Q44T2S7270UU9LCNBEK8E2Q41Q5R6VNWZ976J20AOX Granted, Republican approval ratings are in the toilet, so - as I always say - "A well mannered turnip could win this", but I don't know who the candidates are yet.  This could be another uncontested election.

This seat is rated R safe, now just likely Republican. OConner is getting the endorsements but unknown how much he's raised as he entered the race late. Money matters as they head into 3 elections between now and November. Don't see Dems winning here.
The district leans republican and the last two elections have been 2:1 in favor of republicans. That said, given democratic enthusiasm I think this the district is more competitive than normal.
